data.title: LibGDX black screen on rooted Android 5+ devices
data.body:
When running even the basic LibGDX setup example on a rooted Android 5 device, i only get black screens once SuperSU has asked for (and given) permission to access.

This concerns all versions of LibGDX. It's easy to reproduce. Just Setup a default LibGDX installation and add some code for hiding the Android systembar for instance:

`Process proc = Runtime.getRuntime().exec(new String[]{"su","-c","service call activity 79 s16 com.android.systemui"});
proc.waitFor();`

Debugging the app shows it's rendering. I noticed that touches also aren't registered in LibGDX when running black.

This all does work on Android 4 and lower

Please help!

data.title: Generate kotlin source files instead of java when "Use Kotlin" selected in gdx-setup
data.body:
Most likely users want to work with pure Kotlin source files or as much as they can when they selected to use Kotlin for project in gdx-setup.

Notable changes are
* Add kotlin template files for all launcher classes, and core's main class. These are for project generation to use.
* Checking is based on `Language` for its `JAVA` and `KOTLIN`, and for HTML target, also check `gwtSupported` flag.
* Change kotlin version to `1.1.3` instead of `1.1.1` as there should be no major reason to hang back and use older version of kotlin.

**PS**. Actually there's 1 single commit that relevant to this changes. But due to I update my forked repo to latest libgdx after my [previous PR](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/4741) gets merged. Advice is welcome on how to squeeze it to only 1 commit before merging.

data.title: VertexArray needlessly creates DirectFloatBufferU
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.

#### Issue details
When using a SpriteBatch on Desktop:
In VertexArray.bind(shader, locations), it passes ```byteBuffer``` to ```shader.setVertexAttribute```, although it actually *has* a FloatBuffer.
The ```ShaderProgram``` now calls ```glVertexAttribPointer``` which in turn calls ```asFloatBuffer()```, because the buffer is not a ```GL_FLOAT```.

I guess just passing ```buffer``` instead of ```byteBuffer``` in ```com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.VertexArray#bind(com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram, int[])``` should do the trick.

#### Reproduction steps/code
This is difficult to reproduce in that it requires a profiler (like jvisualvm) to be connected to observe.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.6

data.title: Make Skin class use file a FileHandleResolver for solving file references within the json file
data.body:
#### Issue details
libGDX provides a great way for the developers to implement their own file resolvers and loaders. Unfortunately, there are parts of the libGDX code itself that does not support these yet. The Skin class is one of those. Basically, you cannot use the Skin class along with JSON files based skins if you have defined a custom FileHandleResolver because the Skin class code won't rely on it. 

#### Reproduction steps/code
I think all the involved code is within this method of the Skin class:

`protected Json getJsonLoader (final FileHandle skinFile)`

There are several file resolutions there that can be modified to rely on the FileHandleResolver approach and thus be made compatible with custom resolvers, just to pick the first one:


```
FileHandle fontFile = skinFile.parent().child(path);
if (!fontFile.exists()) fontFile = Gdx.files.internal(path);
if (!fontFile.exists()) throw new SerializationException("Font file not found: " + fontFile); 

```

This should be better written as:

```
FileHandle fontFile = resolver(path);
if (!fontFile.exists()) throw new SerializationException("Font file not found: " + fontFile); 
```

This would require some additional changes in the Skin class to have such resolver available. At least a way to provide the the resolver. It could be as easy as add this parameter to some of its constructors, much as it is done in the AssetManager class, for example:


```
/** Creates a new AssetManager with all default loaders. */
	public AssetManager (FileHandleResolver resolver) {

/** Creates a new AssetManager with optionally all default loaders. If you don't add the default loaders then you do have to
	 * manually add the loaders you need, including any loaders they might depend on.
	 * @param defaultLoaders whether to add the default loaders */
	public AssetManager (FileHandleResolver resolver, boolean defaultLoaders) {

```

It should be a matter of extrapolating that approach to the Skin class itself.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies
1.9.3 and probably every other version 

#### Please select the affected platforms
- [X] Android
- [X] iOS (robovm)
- [X] iOS (MOE)
- [X] HTML/GWT
- [X] Windows
- [X] Linux
- [X] MacOS

Just read the two years old article about the maven deployment that is still not finished.

You don't need to rebuild stuff using maven just to deploy it to maven central. Actually, it would be better, in order to have identical binaries, to not do that. data.title: my game is freezing with "intel_do_flush_locked failed: Input/output error"
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.

#### Issue details
At random times during my game, it completely freezes.  About 10 seconds later it exits and prints this message:

```
intel_do_flush_locked failed: Input/output error
AL lib: (EE) alc_cleanup: 1 device not closed
```

#### Issue details

Perhaps it has something to do with the Steam overlay, but it doesn't happen on any other platform I've tried so I don't know what to do. The Steam support guys didn't have very much to say on the matter either. 

Anyone else who have run into this issue?

data.title: Xbox360 controller's left/right trigger button didn't recognized and received event
data.body:
Please ensure you have given all the following requested information in your report.

#### Issue details

Xbox360 controller either wired or wireless whose trigger buttons on left and right are not recognized by `Controllers` extension of libgdx `1.9.6`.

#### Reproduction steps/code

You can just try to create a new project with `Controllers` extension, then try to catch left or right trigger button, you will see that there's no such event received.

Or just follow the following step to test on my project on Github that is ready to be pulled down and tested right away.

1. Pull down the project from [here](github.com/haxpor/raceplant).
2. In `main` branch, checkout `0660f5c`.
2. Plug in your Xbox360 controller to your computer.
3. Try to add debug printing something out to test these [lines](https://github.com/haxpor/raceplant/blob/0660f5ccdbff89c1e92db0b89014d81557bdf727/core/src/io/wasin/raceplant/handlers/BBInputProcessor.kt#L149-L154), or set a breakpoint whether or not it actually reach certain that line when left or right trigger buttons are pressed, or just print `buttonCode` inside `buttonDown()` function.
4. Build and run the project.
5. Try to press left or right trigger button.
6. You will see that there is **no** event received when left or right trigger buttons are pressed.

#### Version of LibGDX and/or relevant dependencies


* libgdx `1.9.6`
* Xbox360 controller driver for macOS from [here](https://github.com/360Controller/360Controller/releases) with latest of `0.16.5`. (note that I cannot see trigger buttons in their Binding section of their configuration setting in System Preferences of macOS, not sure this is also related).

#### Stacktrace

There is no stacktrace as it's no error, but event upon pressing or releasing such buttons are not sent to overridden class of `ControllerListener`.

data.title: AssetManager fails to load different dependencies with same file name
data.body:
#### Issue details

When resolving dependencies, `AssetManager` only distinguishes by file name and not by type. This leads to dependencies with same file name but different type not being loaded.

#### Reproduction steps/code

- create custom `AsynchronousAssetLoader`
- add two dependencies with same file name but different type

I have created an example that demonstrates the bug [here](https://github.com/winniehell/libgdx-duplicate-dependency-filename/blob/master/core/src/de/winniehell/libgdx/duplicatedependencyfilename/DuplicateDependencyFileName.java).

#### Version of LibGDX
1.9.6

#### Stacktrace
```
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: Asset not loaded: ingredient
	at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.get(AssetManager.java:148)
	at de.winniehell.libgdx.duplicatedependencyfilename.DuplicateDependencyFileName.create(DuplicateDependencyFileName.java:111)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication.mainLoop(LwjglApplication.java:149)
	at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl.LwjglApplication$1.run(LwjglApplication.java:126)
```

This happens when accessing the [Pear dependency](https://github.com/winniehell/libgdx-duplicate-dependency-filename/blob/master/core/src/de/winniehell/libgdx/duplicatedependencyfilename/DuplicateDependencyFileName.java#L111) which should have been loaded [here](https://github.com/winniehell/libgdx-duplicate-dependency-filename/blob/master/core/src/de/winniehell/libgdx/duplicatedependencyfilename/DuplicateDependencyFileName.java#L93).

#### Please select the affected platforms
All, but tested only on

- [ ] Android
- [ ] iOS (robovm)
- [ ] iOS (MOE)
- [ ] HTML/GWT
- [ ] Windows
- [x] Linux
- [ ] MacOS

#### Probable cause

I think the bug was introduced by 14ac0c9639880a10c50c85e83236351cd996c986. [This line](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/14ac0c9639880a10c50c85e83236351cd996c986#diff-f4157411d9517868c26e594fec9cf3f4R385) only checks the file name and not the type.
